displayed_text:
Family Member: He’s at M___ because I worked there. Doctor: That used to be C____> Family Member: Yeah. Patient: Mm,hmm. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Will you make your own appointment with him? Family Member: I can. I mean whatever I need to do, just let me know. I’ll do it. (pause) Doctor: Yeah um. Do you want to talk to him soon?
FAM Probably. I know you don’t necessarily start soon. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: In terms of getting hormone therapy do you want to do it with us? He could do it too. Family Member: Oh, well, he only has to come in how often for that? Doctor: The most common way is once every three months. Family Member: Okay.

Patient: Well okay so you’re talking three different options. Doctor: Yeah basically. Patient: Which one, which one I guess was your recommendation? Doctor: What I was going to propose is that we do things in parallel. Okay? I was going to sort of leave the chemotherapy as a last possible option only because you have it available at any time. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: You know we can go to it if none of these work or even after they work and then stop working after sometime. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. And who knows what we may have by then too. If you don’t need it at all at that time. The, the I was going to sugg-propose that we do the prescreening and the blood test in anticipation of doing that testing for your blood today. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And that way we have at least that cooking… Family Member: Check the markers and? Doctor: Right. If the markers are positive, I think you should go on the Niraparib, the PARP inhibitor - the targeted treatment…

Patient: Mm,hmm. Doctor: - like a bread loaf. (Makes slicing sound) Family Member: Mm,hmm. Doctor: from before and there were three spots that only had a little bit of cancer. Family Member: Mm,hmm. Doctor: We talked about that on the phone, that’s I don’t know how to explain that. Family Member: I don’t know how you miss all that. Doctor: It would look like the needle would hit more. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Mm,hmm. Doctor: Do you want this. There’s the picture over here. Those are the slices. Family Member: Okay.

Family Member: everyone gets chemo. Which is great for me, you’re like wow, I guess it’s great for you but you know we all have mixed feelings a little bit. I get that. Patient: Right. Doctor: The second study is chemotherapy plus an immunotherapy versus chemotherapy. So, docetaxel plus immunotherapy versus docetaxel. So, you know, either one of those is doable. Again, if you had stuff outside of bone that’s probably what we should do. Hi, oh, for the opioids, Okay, for your pain, yeah. So, then the other part is what if you’re just bone. So, let’s say we do this and you’re just in your bones, no lymph nodes, liver, nothing, it’s clean then I think we should consider radium or Xofigo. Family Member: Together with the docetaxel? Doctor: No, just radium. So, there it’s um to combine with anything else is not standard of care and we don’t have our trial up yet with radium plus something. But, at this moment standard of care is just monthly radium for six months and that improves your survival span. So does chemotherapy but radium you can only give if it’s just in bone. So, if you have it like in the liver or whatever kind of like when we first started Patient: Um hum. Doctor: it was like oh, no you kind of had these bits and pieces, Patient: Right. Doctor: one, your insurance won’t approve it and number two it’s the wrong treatment. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But, if that’s sort of gone and nowhere to be found on this CAT scan then I think radium is it. Now, radium does two things. One is that it helps you live longer but also helps with pain so those people who are, you know, whether you’re taking a Tylenol over-the-counter or you’re taking actual narcotics that should improve. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Okay. Healthcare Professional: Do you want me to step out for a few? Doctor: I just uh, you can stay, I mean it doesn’t matter to me. I did realize I wasn’t quite done because I had gone back to get paperwork. Healthcare Professional: Alright well I’ll step out. Doctor: Yeah like give me like two minutes, we’ll be set. Okay (door closes) Patient: Okay. (Pause 30 seconds) Doctor: Here you go. If you can sign here. Here you go. (sound of signing papers) Healthcare Professional 1: Sorry, just me. So I sent all your scripts (door closes) Patient: Okay. Healthcare Professional 1: …electronically to the K____ pharmacy. Patient: Okay, thanks. Healthcare Professional 1: That’s your oxycodone, the Xanax and that the – this is the one to help you urinate. That’s Tamsulosin which is generic for Flomax. All your other medications, your vitamins, prednisone, your cholesterol medication, everything else.

Family Member: I think it’s a echocardiogram… Healthcare Professional: Phase I. Patient: Can I bring a book? Doctor: Oh yeah, yeah. They even have movies and they have a TV there. Family Member: You’re gonna bring me too. I’m definitely coming to this. Doctor: They have all kinds of stuff to do there. Patient: Do they have people that know how to put in an IV? Doctor: Yes they do. Well yeah. Family Member: So you think it would be one IV and then all the drugs through the IV? Doctor: Right. Yeah. Family Member: That’s much better. Doctor: That way you don’t get poked five times. If you have five blood draws.

Patient: Yeah, yeah. (chuckles) Doctor: This is such a generous gift. Today today I am wearing my uh socks. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: You know Patient: Oh they talking about sending some in December, you heard. Just some socks. Doctor: I did. Patient: Yeah, mhm. Doctor: But next time you come in I going to have to wear these. Doctor: The polka dot socks. Patient: Yeah. (laughs) Doctor: Perfect. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: It goes there for now. How have you been?

Patient: Right. Doctor: So the one is with Vitamin C. The one with the immune therapy. So I’m putting down an appointment for you to see me in a month. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You can check on my chart or you and Dr. G__ decide something earlier, or you need to see us earlier, the scans are made, you can see me earlier; that doesn’t mean I’m going to start you earlier. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But you know if it’s sort of you would rather do chemo with us rather than closer to home or if one of these studies makes sense, then we will be available or just to check in to sort of see where you are with some of these decision processes. Vital signs Your my chart, you’re already hooked in. These are the medicines I think you’re taking. Patient: Now I go for -I go for pulmonology tests, I think it’s tomorrow, maybe Thursday. Thursday, and but I don’t see a pulmonologist until early March, second of March. Doctor: Yeah. Maybe Dr. G can get thing done Patient: Yeah, I don’t know. Doctor: Some of that might be based on the CAT scan and your tests if they’re you know really at normal or suggestive of something, then that may open doors to get into the lung doctor in a fast - Patient: I understand. Doctor: ah I don’t have any paperclips here. So there are two different numbers here, so J.

Patient: So, you’re, you’re trying to drive the level, the level down so when the surge happens, it doesn’t peak, or it peaks as low as it - Family Member: Okay. Patient: Yay. Hhh (chuckles) Family Member: So, until Doctor: So, I’ll, I’ll start that. You’re gonna need to sign a permission and all that with T_. Healthcare Professional: Yep. Doctor: And, she’ll go over all the, the, the other detail, which you’ve already read. You know, this is the opportunity for you to ask me questions and see if there is any reason that you want to abort, uh, or say this is the right way to go. Uh, and, then, I’ll get your medicines written and plan for your hormone shot in two weeks. And, then, we can leave it a little bit up in the air between T_, myself, as to what, uh day per our calendar when you wanna just say, “Okay, this is…” Patient: Well, well, well, we’ll work within that, that four-week window of the month. That has to start with - I just, again, if we, if the advice was to start same day, I would. If you wait four weeks, we will pick a date four weeks out and start then. Doctor: Yeah, and if he had a little bit more flexibility, just again, if we started then, and it ends up on Christmas and the holidays. Healthcare Professional: Yeah, Doctor: Yeah. Patient: From when I talk to people, first dose of chemo, most of the guys that I talk to, not a huge impact effect with nausea or, or anything. Um, it was the second or third that they really started to feel um -
